UPDATED: DEC 1, 2010 Pours jet black and thick like 10W40 with a thick and pillowy mocha like head.  Pretty sticky as evidenced by each passing sip and another ring around the glass.  Aromas of chocolate, coffee, vanilla and ash abound.  That is hardly its most enticing part.  If anything its nose is just as good as other above average stouts.  Flavorful brew....semi-sweet Bakers chocolate, burnt oak, leather and cold espresso marry nicely.  I find the attributes that set it apart more from others is an ominpresent vanilla sweetness and the drying, bitterness on the finish of the cocoa powder.  Oily and thick....a real tooth coater.  This is easily  sessionable and definitely a quality product.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2013 pours dark brown-black with a thick crema head, excellent retention and lacing. roastiness plenty, cocoa, bourbon, vanilla, chocolate, coffee, leather, woody, excellent hops to support. some sweetness. silky, oily, velvety, medium to heavy body. excellent stuff.

First tried this beer at the Vermont Brewers Festival but couldnt fully appreciate it due to the heat! Found a 12oz bottle at my local beer store to my surprise! Pours pitch black with a think brown head. Thick, malty aroma with strong dark chocolate notes. Full bodied, smooth, sweet stout. You get a stout with balanced malt, mild hop character, and a noticeable amount of chocolate. You can definitely smell and taste the chocolate but this is no where near as chocolaty as Youngs of Southern Tiers chocolate stouts! A bit of vanilla coming through but not too much, maybe just enough to help mellow out the chocolate. Overall a stellar beer! If you can find it, dont be a fool...try this beer!

A: The pour is a dark brown color with a massive tan head and a ton of carbonation.

S: The nose is rich and chocolate filled. Great sweet milk chocolate notes, vanilla, and a more subtle roasted character and a dark caramel note as well.

T: Like the nose, plenty of sweet milk chocolate, cocoa, and vanilla. A more pronounced roasted flavor along with some slightly burnt notes.

M: The body is medium with a fairly high carbonation that actually works alright.

D: Not quite as good as Peche Mortel, but still nice. Definitely overcarbonated, but a vigorous pour and some time in the glass helps to smooth that out.

Pours black with a extremely thin white head and good carbonation. Aroma is very heavy on the malts and vanilla but also includes notes of chocolate and roasted barley. Flavor is a tad on the sweet side with the vanilla and milk chocolate flavors shining through. Very good beer, I would probably say it falls more into the category of a sweet stout, which is fine with me.
Much thanks to Julien for the trade.  Nice chocolate and toast aroma.  Sweetness with chocolate and vanilla cola flavor.  Tingly carbonation but goes down smooth.  Light on alcohol.  Very nice.

Very little head. Nose was very slight and coffee with little else. Flavour very robust coffee at first, rich cocoa as the beer reached room temperature. Very overwhelming flavour, good as a dessert beer with berries but difficult to have with any food with more subtle flavours.  Much better warm than chilled, even slightly.

This is one great smelling, fabulous tasting beer.  Its probably the most chocolatey beer Ive ever had and it shows remarkable balance with a very subtle sweetness and just enough bitterness.   The head is not impressive at all, detracting a little, but otherwise a stellar beer, and easily one of my favorites.  Another win for dieu du ciel!
Bière Stout aux fèves de cacao et à la vanille, 6.5% dalcool, peu mousseuse, bien houblonné.

Deep thick black pour with a tan head.  Aroma is almost like cream soda, but not cloying, vanilla and chocolate with some really subtle roasted hints.  Flavored beer can be overwhelming (Southern Tier Creme Brulee, Im looking at you!) but this had the perfect balance of sweet vanilla and milk chocolate and roasted barley.  Great balance.  Wonderful dessert beer.   Iwas sad to see the bottom of my glass on this one.  Tasty.

Happy Halloween.  My bottle is labeled as Aphrodite.  What an amazingly seductive pour ... rich black with a towering head of tight tan foam.  The aroma is sweet, with the vanilla up front.  The beer drinks much sweeter than anticipated as well -- not as richly chocolatey as Id expected but rather light instead, an unanticipated character.  This would still be delicious with a slice of German chocolate cake, though.  (#4007, 10/31/2010)

11.5 oz bottle, pours black with a small creamy mocha head. Aroma is very strong vanilla, extract, sweet and chocolatey, some dark fruitiness, a bit of chocolate covered fruit and coffee beans. Flavor starts very rich and sweet, a touch of maple and coffee, becoming more like bitter chocolate through the swallow with some vanilla aftertaste and a touch of roast. Medium to medium full creamy body and a softer carbonation. Excellent stout.

341mL bottle - BB 3/11
Opaque deep dark brown body, thick tan head persists.
Confectionary chocolate on the nose; very intense. Toasted biscuity malt in there and toffee supported by sweet vanilla bean and clove spice.
Slick oily texture, low carbonation, medium body is a bit leaner than I was expecting.
Milk chocolate persists on the body, with nutty malts and rich caramel. Not nearly as sweet as the aroma suggests. Vanilla and spice lingers on a long finish with plenty of roast bitterness drying on the tongue.
Suprisingly drinkable, and undoubtedly delicious, chocolate stout. The balance is amazingly well done.

This beer really has that WOW! this is un-real factor to it.
Its a big, dark black brew with a creamy beige coloured head. on the nose it is extremely explosive :RICH vanilla notes, creamy latte and expresso notes and even some brown sugar in there. WOW i say! on the palate it delivers with all those creamy and bread batter notes are there but the vanilla and chocolate notes explode! Im in love!

341ml bottle.  Pours black with a mocha coloured head.  HUGE aromas of cocoa, hot chocolate, followed by coffee, caramel, alcohol, and faint vanilla.  This is one of the best smelling beers Ive encountered.  Starts medium sweet with big notes of molasses, and espresso followed by dried fruits, faint alcohol, with just the slightest hint of vanilla, and copper.  Citrus in the bitter finish.   A huge beer.  One of the best beers Ive tried.  SOOO recommended.

12oz btl. Pours just as inky dark as youd think with a fingers worth of tan head. Great strong cocoa aroma with definite vanilla. Very rich toasted malt aroma. More medium bodied than Id have guessed. Nice sweey roasted malty start into a crisp hoppiness followed by a long bittersweet finish. I like that this isnt 11 percent. A great stout.

UPDATED: APR 9, 2011 Phenomenal beer.  Dark colour ale with just the right hint of vanilla, roasted malt and chocolate.  Very smooth.  My only negative is that I bought two at the LCBO, but now Im back in Vancouver and may not be able to get more!  =( .  Rerated 4/9/2011 after another taste.  Still delish!
Labeled as Aphordite.   Wonderful roasted chocolate and vanilla aromas. Sweet dark chocolate,  vanilla and molassas flavors.  Overall an awesome stout for chilly fall night.
Keg.  Big chocolatey aroma and initial taste, but surprisingly light and refreshing body.   Vanilla and chocolate flavours.  Lingering aftertaste of vanilla and cocoa.
Aroma is subtle with mostly milk chocolate. Taste is more burnt and reminiscent of dark chocolate. Slightly disappointing.

The phrases, oh my god, oh god yes,oh dear baby jesust, and dear lord, all come to mind. 
This stuff is the bomb, its awesome, seriously fantastic stuff.
The aroma is roasty,  but with HUGE vanilla notes, and light undertones of chocolate cake in the oven, tapering off with notes of licorice. The flavour is oh dear god, delicious, smooth, light, drinkable, but super full of complex flavours, roasty malts, chocolate, coffee, lots of vanilla, some more chocolate, finishes with notes of licorice. God bless you dieu du ciel!

341ml bottle, fairly fresh> Puts a pitch black opaque elixir in the goblet with a massive mocha-colored creamy cap...fair retention, great lacing quality.

Aroma is deep roasted cocoa bean, some coffee, some oak, a very light honey-vanilla under tone and wet straw mingles with fusel.

Medium bodied firm mouth feel, bitter-dark roast cocoa character.

Front has roasty malts, cocoa bittering and hop spiciness in perfect balance....mid palate no complexity develops just the 3 major tasts starting to go roasty-bitter in the finish.

Well crafted, decent cocoa stout but the complexity I expected never developed. At only 6.5% abv, this really isnt a cellar beer but Im going to put a couple down for a few months to see if I can bring that buried honey-earthy tone to the front and see some mild complexity.

Bottle.  Pours a translucent brown color with an off white head.  Aroma is chocolate, like Yoohoo, with some vanilla.  Bitter finish with a slight rusty taste.  The finish is too light, doesnt really round out the beer.  Medium body.

Poured a coal colored body with a small head. Had a slight cocoa, vanilla scent. Was expecting more. Strong alcohol taste up front, finishing with a fantastic cocoa and coffee flavor. Would recomend and drink again.

Bottle, tfs Vaiz! Solid black pour, small tanned head. Aroma is very chocolaty, roasted malt, some vanilla and coffee.
Flavour is very roasty chocolate, sweet at first, quite bitter with coffee in the finish. Very nice, very full for the abv.

Bottle. Stellar brew. deep black wonderful brew with a sturdy beige head  and moderate lacing. The nose is roasted malt, vanilla, cocca and vanilla. The mouth is an exquisite complex parlay of coffee, roasted malts, cocca, bitter chocolate and vanilla. There is a moderate level of carbonantion with a lush and creamy mouthfeel. I agree that the vanilla is present, but not over powering. Delightful and a treat to linger over.
Cask. Dark brown color. Aroma is vanilla, chocolate, sirup, oiled wood and a light smokiness. Taste of wood and tar. Quite bitter. Dry mouth feel.
nose of heavy port, cane sugar, coffee, and chocolate, heavy syrupy feel and wellbalanced carb. taste is chocolate, roasted coffee and banana

Bought at Les Fleurs du Malt in Lyon, France, not knowing how appraised this beer was here. Heavy cacao powder in the aroma. Bitter coffee in the flavor. Roasted and still slightly sweet. Only the vanilla is slightly sweet. Maybe oak age this one someday? Well balanced. Heavy flavor while still very drinkable. Nice.

Bière noire de 6.5 % dalcool. Parfum et goût de vanille et mélangé au goût avec du chocolat noir. Goût à sensation acre au début, mais on découvre un goût très intéressant. Soupçon de café (ou de cacao comme le mentionne la description de la bouteille). Bière épaisse et col moyen au versement.

Pours black with a tan head. Big cocoa chocolate nose. A rich body supports intense cocoa flavours, which eventually yield to the black malt.  Vanilla is detectable throughout but never intrusive. A wonderfully rounded choccy stout.

Bottle - thanks bigmmartin.  Pours dark brown with a modest tan head.  Light bits of sticky lacing.  Very sweet and seductive aroma is light with roast and vanilla, heavier in the cocoa.  Smooth and rich flavor really does a magnificent job of blending the vanilla, cocoa, and roast seemlessly.  Ever so slight bittersweetness in the tail.  Just delicious.

Big aroma hit of vanilla straight off the bat. Lots of good cocoa there too which makes this beer quite a complex one. lovely smooth mouthfeel with plenty more vanilla and cocoa flavour to go with the aroma.

Bottle. Wow, incredibly beautiful pour, deep black with pretty off-tan head. nose is rich vanilla extract, smells like a pastry kit chen. Cocoa nibs, some coffee bitters. Taste is alc-vanilla, so much like a beer version of cooking vanilla extract. Finishes a touch dry and a bit light. Big flavor but not totally full. Quite great.

WOW!  This beer is terrific.  Poured from a bottle into a snifter.  Aroma of coffee and vanilla with a hint of chocolate.  Pours black with a nice tan head.  Flavors of coffee and vanilla spread nicely across the tongue, with a hint of alcohol bite on the end, nice, complex flavors but not overpowering, very well done.  Palate is nice and full-bodied, goes down dangerously smoothly.  Overall, I am very much impressed with this offering from Dieu Du Ciel.

Bottle from Sams Quik Stop on 03/07/2010 as Aphrodite. Dark black body with a medium creamy light brown head. Big chocolate, cocoa, roast and light caramel aroma. Big chocolate flavor, some cocoa, roast, chocoalte and light caramel. Medium light body with moderate carbonation.

Courtesy of After4ever, thanks Tom. Its black with a dark-brown, creamy head and the aroma has notes of roasted malt, orange-chocolate, cocoa and vanilla. The flavour is sweet with notes of roasted malt, orange-chocolate, berries, cocoa, vanilla and the finish is dry, Im not fond of the notes of orange-chocolate in this otherwise nice beer.
Smells heavenly. I wish all stouts smelled like this. Vanilla and tons of chocolate and honey. Nice and strong flavor with a great bitter flavor to balance.

Bottle graciously provided by ketchepillar. Pours black with a small but persistent head leaving a nice bit of lace. The aroma is dark chocolate and some berries with a bit of odd mustiness. The flavor is very bitter and dry with lots of raw coco and a bit of mild vanilla. I love how dry this beer is without being wrenching, its a rare stout that can pull of with this one does. The finish has a note of acidic coffee. The palate is slick with a mild but noticeable carbonation.

Bottle @ Boise Imperial Stout Tasting: Dark black pour with thick edges, tall head and a small film of lacing. The nose is roasty and sweet with a nuggat and milk chocolate note. The flavor is sweet and toasty with an overwhelming flavor of cocoa puffs. Its uncanny how much this tastes like that popular breakfast cereal. I can still taste it, must be the fair trade cocoa and vanilla beans.

12oz bottle from New Beer Distributors. Med tan head. Light aroma. Buttery. Fridge-y. Not bad, just bleh. Flavor is another story. Lots going on, most good, some not. Some nice vanilla. Definitely cocoa-y. Really nice cocoa. Interesting mellow smooth caramel character. A bit of diacetyl. Slick palate. Very light melony fruitiness. Aroma is better as it warms.

"in a word...yum. the cocoa in this beer was done just right. not overpowering, but definitely not in the background either. of course, none of that would matter if it wasnt atop a well crafted balanced bittersweet stout, but it was. was it ever! great beer - ill be looking for it again."
UPDATED: OCT 7, 2013 A very, very good stout.  Lots of great vanilla and slight cocoa flavors.  Medium-heavy roasted characteristic, and a body like a fuller, higher ABV stout.  Just a good beer.
Bottle. Black with a brown head. Nicely balanced flavours of chocolate, vanilla, hints of coffee, with a nice bitterness.

My advice to homebrewers who wish to brew chocolate beers is always to add some vanilla. The richness the vanilla imparts in this beer is exactly why. It emphasizes the chocolate flavors just like it does in chocolate cake and the like. The color here is brown, nearly black w/ only a very small bit of tan bubbles around the rim. The nose is of rich chocolate desserts, big time cocoa w/ a solid push of vanilla to back it up. This really is a wonderful balancing act by Dieu du Ciel. Its just sweet enough to bring out the chocolate and only bitter enough to balance the sweetness. I might complain that this is maybe a little thinner than Id think ideal, perhaps on account of just a hair too much carbonation, but that is really minor as the richness of the well done chocolate vanilla combo more than makes up for it. Most beers that seem to fill the dessert niche are things that youd only want to drink a small amount of but this is a very welcome exception.

341 ml bottle from Premier Wine & Spirits (Halifax).  Pours a rich, oily looking near-black dark brown with small beige head.  Aroma is roasty, somewhat bitter, somewhat sweet with dark chocolate, coffee, and light vanilla notes that emerge increasingly as the beer warms.  Taste is a nice balance of roasty and sweet with strong cocoa flavour and subtle but apparent vanilla.  Solid hop presence, nice bitterness in finish.  Delicate carbonation.  Very good.
Une des meilleures bières noires québécoise que jai goûté. Jadore le côté vanille qui la rend si particulière.

Bottle, thank you so much for this gem Fred! Fat chocolate aroma - milk chocolate base with bitter notes on top. Opaque black with fine brown lace. Vanilla, pipe tobacco, ripe dates, coffee and cocoa, grassy hops linger in the background. Mellow mouthfeel,  roasted sparkly finish, dry dark chocolate aftertaste. Beautiful rich treat.

Easy to see why this is so well regarded. Brilliant use of bitter roast and chocolate and hops to produce a firm and well balanced stout that seems to have so much seriousness about it. Not at all soft and sweet but not crazy bitter either. Seems to have the structure to be aged nicely. Tangy fruity like to finish.  Excellent.

Pours with a chocolate head that settles to 1cm and fades very quickly. Aroma of Mocha and tastes a complex mix of dark cocoa bitterness and coffee but also incredibly well balanced and smoothness. Damn good beer.

12oz bottle.  Love this when it first came out.  Appears very dark brown with coffee color head.  Aroma is vibrant cocoa and roasted coffee with a hint of vanilla.  The cocoa and vanilla hit the palate first then a nice drier mid with a sweeter finish.  For the alc % and style its one of the best moderately prices stouts out there.  Will always recommend.

En vanilj- och chokladstout på vänliga 6,5%. Stor doft av söt mörk frukt, vanilj och choklad. Smaken tar vid där doften slutar. Ett snällt öl med liten beska, relativt fylligt. Drucken på Nya Tröls en trevlig kväll med Johan

Intensely black syrupy pour with tan head.  The aroma is very sweet and roasty.  Very strong chocolate/cocoa/vanilla, oak, bourbon notes....all pretty much in synchronisty and balance.   I drink this a instead of dessert and somehow convince myself that its healthier than bread pudding and whipped cream...I guess the alcohol helps the self-deceipt gain a measure of credibility.

Almost opaque black pour with ruby hues and a chocolate foam head that reduces to a tiny fringe bubbles.  Pure vanilla extract to the nose, alongside some lightly smoked roasted peat.  Flavors are dry, of vanilla, roasted coffee, cocoa, smoke and roasted grains abounding.  They congregate in a dry roasted, slightly acidic finish.  A smooth mouthfeel and medium body makes for a slick, creamy palate.  Great, great complex dry stout!  Substantive, easy drinking and delicious!

12 oz bottle from Belmont Station. Pours the deepest brown imaginable with a lovely mocha brown head. Smells of chocolate, vanilla, nuts and some light cracker. Tastes of chocolate, vanilla, dark grains and some nice charred notes. Delicious brew, I would not quibble with its spot atop the list of stouts.

bottle almost exploded. insane carbonation gives way to a complete gusher. maybe a 6 oz pour when all is settled. also gives rise to a harsh mouthfeel.  black body with the massive beige head as described. aroma of sour notes, coffee, burnt toast, and cocoa. flavor of bitter cocoa, coffee grounds, vanilla, and earthy hops (including a grassy, dry finish). sour backbone...

Pours a nice dark colour with a two finger head which dissipates but leaves a nice lasing. nice strong aroma of dark chocolate and coffee. taste sweet chocolate and vanilla caramel flavour. very smooth aftertaste and no trace of the 6.5 % alc.
tap at taphouse. dark beer with flavours of dark choc, caramel, vanilla, and roasted malts. needed slightly more bittering for me.

12 oz bottle labeled as aphrodite, purchased from Osheas in CA - Pours an opaque black color with light tan head that dissipates fairly quickly. Aroma has a fair amount of chocolate, toasted marshmellow, touch of roastyness, vanilla bean. Flavor is fairly roasty, bit of vanilla and oaky tannins. Finish is fairly balanced. Palate is somewhat thin. This is not bad, but fairly dissapointing considering that I have been crazy to try this for ages.

Bottle shared with frosty. pours black and a medium brown head not staying around long but comes back with every swirl. Nose is dominated by roast malt, vanilla, coffee, dark chocolate and really stellar. Taste is lots of roasted bitterness, bitter chocolate and dry finish. Carbonation starts off the mouthfeel and and thin. Overall a great dry stout with plenty of character. would try again.

Draught @ Ölrepubliken, Göteborg. Dark brown color with an almost nonexisting head. Nice aroma with a lot of coffee and vanilla. The taste is a disapointment, way too sweet with a too light body. There is also vanilla and roast. Very bitter finish. Reminds of icecoffee with vanilla flavour.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2011 Draft. Pours pitch black with a dark brown nitro head. Flavor is chocolate, vanilla, coffee. Like drinking chocolate milk!

Re-rate: Even better than I remember. Truly the best low abv stout money can buy!

UPDATED: APR 7, 2016 Bouteille 341 ml. 6.5%. Couleur noire comme la nuit, mousse beige persistante. Douce, moelleuse et apaisante. Arôme de chocolat, café, vanille et malt rôti. En bouche, lentrée provient de la vanille et du café, le chocolat suit et une amertume correct prend sa place. Finale un peu sucrée, vanillée, chocolatée. Une bière incroyable, bien balancée, réconfortante et enivrante. Délicieuse.

Bottle.  Dark brown-blackish pour with a thin brown head.  Aroma of coffee and bitter chocolate.  Mild carbonation with lasting lacing. Taste of roasted malt, bitter chocolate and faint bourbon.  Lasting, slightly dry finish.

Pours a thick black with tan head, also a darker ring of tan/khaki on the outside, which remains as the lacing as I sip away.  Strong aroma of  vanilla, roasted malt, milk chocolate, coffee.  Similar taste, nice bitter roasted malt/chocolate finish.  Vanilla flavor stays on the tongue and lingers in the finish. Some mild hops evident as well.  Medium bodied. Very well balanced beer.

Fantastic stout. Pours rich and black with a tan head. Aroma is intoxicating - cocoa, smoke, earthen and spicy hops, hints of vanilla beans.  Taste is equally impressive with sweet chocolate slowly yielding to a long, smokey finish far too potent for the faint-of-palate. Wonderfully balanced body, so velvety smooth and robust that is coats and cleanses the throat during its descent. Simply marvelous.
Great contrasting aroma of both dark chocolate and vanilla. Taste is full of cocoa, vanilla, and maybe even a hint of bourbon.

Hahahahaha! Man, I caint believe my good luck! Nother fabulous beer. Ah musta been blest. Or, I just recognised a good beer when I saw it. In any case, this is sublime. Poured with a medium tan to light brown head that settled down to a light cover quickly and some lace. Color is absolute opaque black. Aroma is a sweet blend of melting chocolate, malt, caramel, vanilla, and pipe tobacco. Flavor is like that and lots bigger: all qualities are more prominant along with a definite smokieness. Body is very soft and carbonation just where it should be in this case. Finish is like flavor and very slowly tapers in a long finish. Ultimate after dinner beer.

(11.5 oz. bottle from Tullys) Smooth and intense...Pours very dark brown with three fingers of mocha head that settle to a lumpy, lasting cap. Aroma of big rich dark coffee, dark bitter and semi-sweet chocolate and light vanilla. Mouthfeel smooth and rich, just a light touch of chalkiness past the finish. Flavor of smooth, rich, intense lightly sweetened coffee roast with hints of dark Bakers and semi-sweet chocolate. Moderate bitter finish. Just a feast.

This beer is kinda hard to describe in terms of why it is pretty good.  On one level the carbonation is pretty tame but certainly present.  The beer is quite smooth even right out of the sniffer.  The aroma is malty, rasin with a bit of bite to the air perhaps.  It is slightly bitter but at the same time denotes a definite hint of coffee, bitter sweet chocolate and the most subtle tangy flavor and aroma.  I appreciate this beer but it is not my favorite.  It is sophisticated for the vanilla flavor that is also present.  The bitter finish is the only exception that I find to be off-putting.  That being said this is a pleasant beer but I think that there are other options that Id like to dissect.

(Bottled, sampled 2010-02-05) Very dark brown with a smallish, firm and lasting head. Loads of vanilla and cocoa in the aroma, with some milk chocolate. Smooth cocoa flavor with somewhat roasty coffee, roasted malt, and vanilla spiciness. Medium to full body, soft CO2, not too sweet. A pleasantly balanced, rounded dessert brew.

Bottle. Aroma is of heavy toasted and dark chocolate, light herbs for the hops, with cola and vanilla in the background. Head is small, frothy, light brown with some thin lacing and is mostly diminishing. Color is dark brown, almost black. Flavor starts moderately sweet and lightly acidic, and the long finish is moderately bittersweet. Palate is medium, creamy with a lively carbonation and a dry finish. This is like a carbonated Mexican chocolate drink. So simple, but so well composed.

Pours a black color with a caramel colored soapy head.  Has an aroma of roasted coffee and chocolate.  Sweet start.  Roasty, chocolate taste with some awesome vanilla notes.  Very creamy.  The chocolate flavor is exquisite.  Would love to try this on nitro.

Black pour with a small, short-lived, tan head.  Bitter black coffee aroma with notes of chocolate, sublte vanilla, pronounced hops, touches of dark fruit, brown sugar and a little vgetalness.  Lots of strong dark roast coffee flavor with creamy vanilla, a touch of caramelized brown sugar, creme brulee, and some hop bitterness on the finish.  Oily, medium-full body with moderate carbonation.

341ml bottle. Pours black with a nice toffee coloured head that doesnt stick around. Complex nose of fresh chocolate and vanilla with espresso notes. Stunning mouthfeel; like liquid velvet. Super full bodied yet easy going. When introducing most ladies to dark beer this is a great place to start.
12 oz bottle. Pours black with a small tan head leaving significant lacing on the glass.  Coffee smell and taste.  Medium mouthfeel.  Very smooth.  Tasty beer.

Bottle at beerbistro in Toronto.  Due to the standards board of Ontario they pay someone to black over the word Aphrodisiaque with majic marker because somehow its offensive.  Whats not offesive is this terrific beer a great looking black/purple pour with nice little head.  tastes of chocolate, vanilla, bourbon, and roasted bitterness.  Very nice.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2010 Location: Draft at Rattle N Hum, 7/14/10


Aroma: The nose has lots of chocolate, some coffee, and roasted malts

Appearance: It pours a dark brown color capped by a brown head 

Flavor: The taste is also rather malty with a big dark chocolate feel, some bitterness in the finish

Palate: An extremely smooth, easy drinking stout, with a pretty full bodied feel

Overall Impression: 
This one has some really good chocolate and malt flavors, and I thought it worked really well.  The bar displayed this beer under the name "Aphrodite," but I guess thats some sort of political correctness working its magic...  Anyway, it has a really interesting chocolaty feel to it thats a little different.  The bitterness in the finish kind of had a dark chocolate feel to it.  I really enjoyed this one.

Bottle, Opaque w/ slight purple/mahogany at edges w/ a frothy mocha head, rich chocolate aroma tinged w/ roasted notes, sweet chocolate and roastiness dominate profile w/ the roasted flavor lingering, slightly overcarbonated bite at finish

Jet black body produced a thin latte head that left little webbing.  Aroma is vanilla, roasted coffee bean, cocoa, and oak.  Flavor shows lots of dark bitter chocolate and burnt brown sugar.  The alcohol is present but doesnt overwhelm the palate.  Good not great.

Bottle from TXJeep.Pours a perfect black with a nice java brown head.  Aroma is plastic chocolate with cocoa nibs dispersed casually.  Flavor is plastic-smoked chocolate and cocoa dust.  Average mouthfeel.  Not bad, but not fantastic.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Bottle.  Aroma has notes of dark chocolate, vanilla, espresso, cheap bourbon, damp wood and deep roasted malts.  Very dark brown hue that sits black in the glass with a brown tinge near the edges.  Very little head but what was there was dark tan foam that completely disappears and leaves no lace.  Taste is sweet and roasted bitterness.  Palate is medium bodied and watery soft with bitter finish.  Overall a good brew thats just above average.  I did not enjoy the damp woody bitterness on the finish.  Theres something just a little off there.

Aroma:Hot chocolate with a little bit of alcohol.

Appearance:Black, Tan head, good head retention, poor lacing.

Taste:Delicious! Tons of dark chocolate, a little bit of vanilla. The flavor is the same from the foretaste thru the aftertaste.

Palate:Smooth and creamy with just a little carbonation.

Overall:Chocolaty and delicious, this beer is quite a treat.

Dark chocolate, roast, and a good deal of vanilla. Light earthy woody hop notes as well. Pours dark brown, more or less black with not much in the way of head or lace. Flavors of dark chocolate - bitter, cocoa, roast and vanilla with an earthy mild hop bitterness in the finish. Balanced and well done, but not world class as I had expected.

Bottle from Taphouse liquor store in Park Royal, West Vancouver. Pours nearly black with a super thick, cascading head, beautiful looking beer. Aroma is chocolate, vanilla, roast, coffee. Flavour is chocolate, vanilla, coffee, roast, burnt sugar. Palate is full bodied, medium carbonation finished sweet towards the front then bitter. A great stout for sure, one of the most beautiful looking pours, great flavor, world class.

Pours an opaque black with a very small brown head. There is a strong aroma of chocolate. The beer is very smooth but does have a bite of alcohol. Chocolate flavors are muted with vanilla, which lingers on the tongue. Very well blended.

Sampled at SIBF 2010. Pours a deep, dark brown, with very little head. Velvety smooth, absolutely packed with vanilla (and were talking real vanilla beans here, not the milkshake vanilla you normally find in brews. Its a very gentle brew - I expected a bit more punch - but very tasty. Almost like a candy.

This bottled brew from a bottle shop poured a medium sized head of foamy finely sized brown colored bubbles that were long lasting and left behind an  opaque black colored body with no visible carbonation and a thick foamy lacing. The very nice aroma was of strong  cocoa and dark malts. The mouth feel was tingly at the start and at the finish. The wonderful flavor contained notes of nice toasted malts, mild hops, strong cocoa and dark malt. A wonderful best in class brew.  I really enjoyed this one and decided it was worthy of my 4000th entry.

Bottle  Pours a good black with a small tan head.  The head last okay and produces spotty lacing.  Aroma is vanilla, cocoa, and coffee.  Has a light carbonation.  The flavor is good.  Nice amount of coffee.  A solid bitterness of dark chocolate.  The body is medium.  A slick texture.  Real good mouthfeel.  A strong finish and a real oleasing aftertaste.  I touch light on ABV but very easy drinking and just real good.

341ml bottle. Pours like engine oil, thick and black with a slight tan veil of foam that disappears pretty much straight away. Coffee and vanilla bean aroma with a strong bitter flavour that sits well in the mouth and is quite pleasant. Silky and smooth in the mouth and very enjoyable.
Black, small brown head. Nose is sweet,vanilla,chocolate,dry roast.Sweet vanilla profile,smoky & fatty. Light alcohol heat, medium roast bitter end

Initial pour is opaque, capped with a light head which dissipates relatively quickly. Flavours of vanilla in the aroma, but the taste is dominantely black coffee. The vanilla comes through more as a smoothing agent which battles for the finish with what comes across subtlely as blue cheese. 

Bottom line: This beer is a treat and one to be savoured. Dominated by black coffee, the vanilla acts as a smoothing agent while a nice dry cheese-like flavour finishes it off.

Draft at Ginger Man with James and PJ. Pours obsidian black with a thin, constant, creamy tan head. Aroma of vanilla, chocolate, espresso, roast, bitter hops, and milk. Medium bodied with a smooth, easy, cocoa buttery palate. Finished with classy warmth and spice. Outrageous stout. One of the best I have ever tasted.

Bottle.  Pours black with a nice big beige head.  Nose is sweet with lots of vanilla, cream soda, caramel, cocoa, roasty malts, slight nuttiness.  Beautiful.  Taste is full-bodied, smooth, vanilla is there but not overpowering, lots of dark chocolaty roasty malts, some oak, very slight bitterness.  Finish is dominated by a chocolaty malt flavor.  Overall a very nice dessert beer.

you like chocolate, this beer is chocotastic! .. . pours a dark brown, and has a very solid mouth .. . taste is pure liquid chocolate bar, quite sweet .. . the new extreme chocolate beer! .. . I dont want to hear any more about anyone blowing anything out of their ass. ..

11.5 oz. bottle from Bruisin Ales in Asheville.  Pours black with a luxurious light brown head.  Aromas of chocolate and dark roasted coffee.  Light espresso hits the tongue first but vanilla bean fills the palate with some dark chocolate on the finish.  The vanilla has a lingering effect and is quite welcome in this offering.  However, this is no doubt a coffee stout.  And an excellent one at that.  Yet another fine beer from Dieu du Ciel.

Roasted malt,creamy bitter chcolate,lighter then I thought it would be,flavor is hersheys chocolate syrup saturated roasted malt, I do notice a little of that vanilla,some bitterness in the finish,smooth and flavorful, not sure if its quite a 100 rating

Dark  black with a big creamy brown head. Big aroma of vanilla and roasted malts. Flavor of vanilla, roasted malts, and some smoke. Lightly sweet and bitter, medium bodied, soft carbonation. Pretty good.
Creamy dark roast over rich and vibrant vanilla, little chocolate. strong dusty dark chocolate and gritty texture. vanilla builds in the finish, becomes a touch sticky.

a beer worthy of its lofty rating.  The aroma is great, vanilla dominates with cocoa coming through also.  pours deep black with minimal head.  Taste of vanilla on the forfront with cocoa malt finish.  very smooth, perhaps a little thin.  Very easy drinking.  One of my favourite canadian brews.

A steady pour into my New Belgium much produces a huge dense foamy head that is a nicely browned rich, creamed cocoa color.  The beer is a solid black color that shows some brown notes around its edges.  Huge dark cocoa aromatics couple with aromas of darkly roasted coffee.  The chocolate character is really quite decadent smelling here and is accompanied, or perhaps accentuated by a dark sweetness.  If you really inspect the nose, ample toasted grain notes become noticeable towards the end: toasted, almost burn whole wheat cracker aromas, and rich browned bread crust aromatics become noticeable as does the Stout like roast malt aromas.  I have just realized, after taking my first sip, that the sweetness that I am smelling is is actually vanilla; it is funny how the brain does that, associating vanilla with sweetness because that is usually were one encounters it.

My first sip has me noticing just enough sweetness to accentuate a big dark chocolate note, but the beer ends up finishing quite dry with a bitter cocoa and roast malt character; hops definitely play there part in the bitterness but it is the roasted bitterness that seems to be the more noticed up front.  The vanilla flavors, and aromas for that matter, seemed to be missing, but then I realized the sweetness I had smelled and tasted really wasnt sweetness, but was instead the vanilla notes contributing a perceived sweetness to this beer.  Rich and somewhat viscous feeling on the tongue somehow, despite actually being fairly light bodied for something labeled as vanilla-chocolate stout; really though this is quite rich considering that this is not really malty-sweet.  Some of the roast grain astringency, couples with the dark malt and the vanilla to even contribute a hint of induced Bourbon-barrel flavors.

This is quite a nice beer; rich and satiating without being heavy and the complexity that the vanilla and chocolate brings to the beer is quite appreciated.  My only complaint is that the cocoa / roast bitterness can be a bit too much at times, though the beer definitely needs some of this to balance the up front rich chocolate and pervasive, though restrained vanilla notes.  I could easily drink a lot of this beer if my wallet could afford it.

Appearance  Darks as night, unfiltered stout. No light is getting through. The light brown, Khaki colored  head is about fingers and fades fairly quickly leaving a nice lacing. 

Aroma  There is a very present soft vanilla bean aroma that falls to the background of the huge, chocolately malt smell. Theres a huge dark chocolate aroma from the cocoa and chocolate malt. It reminds of brewing up my own oatmeal stout. No hop aroma as is traditional with stouts. 

Taste  The vanilla been is definitely present but no overwhelming  blends amazingly with the rest of flavors. Nothing worse than vanilla as a dominating flavor in a beer. The bitterness is probably a combination of the chocolate and hops and reminds of eating very high percent cocoa dark chocolate. A real solid dark malt flavor backs up the cocoa and vanilla and lingers around. The mouth feel is lighter than expected but very pleasant and as it warms up the flavors intensify and the hops start to make their presence. Carbonation is spot on for the style.

Verdict  Although I enjoy beers like this at any time of the day, Aphrodite would make an excellent desert beer. Its a very balanced beer considering the adjuncts used with the stout base.
Poured an opaque black with a dark caramel colored head. Huge cocoa and vanilla nose, quite impressive. Had a wonderful cocoa vanilla taste with a dry bitter finish. Very nice brew!
A very dark stout. Its finish leaves a bitter taste. It has the chocolate and coffee notes in it and would pair well with a chocolate desert.

Bottle from Nqualls. Thanks many Nathan. Pour black with a dissipating brown head. Wonderful aroma of dark chocolate, roasted malts, and vanilla. Medium bodied with a nice soft carbonation and silky texture. The flavor is a nice blend of cocoa, vanilla, dark roasted malts, mild coffee, and a hint of dark fruits. Sweetness is just right, not too sweet and not over attenuated. Roast bitterness on the finish, but with no acridity. A little astringency surfaces as it warms. Another fine brew from a great brewery.

An absolutely amazing beer. MY friends associated the flavour with coal, but I found the unique mixture of flavours such as bourbon, vanilla, cocoa, and malts to create one of the most interesting flavours I have ever experienced in a beer. AMAZING!!!!

Wow, as always, Dieu Du Ciel offers quality ! This beer is awesome, given a slightly lower ABV than the Pêché Mortel, this beer offers a better taste where higher ABV wipes the taste. I can taste butter, chocolate, coffee, clove, caramel (lots of it). Brew on tap at the microbrewery. The glassware is amazing and I think this beer deserves and award ! Sell you house and buy tons of this beer !!

12 oz bottle pours dark black, decent tan head.  Aroma is incredibly complex with tons of vanilla, chocolate and hints of fruit.  Decent sweetness and a slightly harsh bitter chocolate finish.  Complex, pretty drinkable and a solid stout.

Bottle. Pours jet black with a smallish tan coloured head which slowly falls away leaving good lacing. Great looking beer. Aromas of raosted malt, dark chocolate some vanilla and just a touch of sourness. Plenty of bitter flavours thanks to the bitter chocolate, coffee and toasted malt. Super smooth mouthfeel. Really nice beer.

this cure all witchs brew pours dark like Texas crude, with a small dissipating head.  The bouquet is coffee and chocolate.  It packs a roasted malt wallop with expresso and chocolate under currents.  With a smooth finish, its a well balanced brew.

Bottle from South Bay Drugs.  Dark dark brown pour, creamy tan head.  Sweet chocolate, roasted malt, vanilla, light smokey notes, and quite creamy.  This is a very nice desert beer, but you would need to be in the mood.  The flavors are quality, but personally the sweetness is to much for me.

Pours a dark chocolate but yields a little light with a thick consistency and creamy head. Aromas of strong cocoa, chocolate, sweet vanilla, blended nicely with a burnt oak wood tone(or just roasted malts to be boring). Flavors yield a nice mixture of the burnt malt tones, little chocolate/cocoa, with the vanilla coming through the end. There are noticeable hops but just come through enough in the finish to notice. Sweet but not overly sweet, bitter but not to bitter, light burnt malty aftertaste, complex but not hard to discover all the flavors. This is a great stout, two thumbs up!

Wonderful heavy vanilla aroma with some light, crisp malt underneath.  Black in the glass with a quickly fading brown head.  Pleasant vanilla and slightly roasted malt notes fading into a fine, lingering cocoa.  The beer expends all of its ammo in the aroma and initial taste.  The finish, however, is way too fast for me and unrewarding.  Ratings be damned - I say worth a try (once) but I will not rebuy.

Thanks to Exiled for sharing this beer. This beer was my youngest brothers 100th beer.

The beer pours dark brown to black with a tan head. The aroma is vanilla, chocolate and smoke. The flavor is milk chocolate, vanilla, roasted malt and light smoke. The beer tastes a whole lot like cream soda. Medium-thick mouthfeel and low carbonation.

Excellent beer.  Body and aroma were very consistent with the style.  I was amazed and impressed with the balance achieved between the rich malt content and the cocoa/vanilla flavorings.  Usually either the cocoa is too overpowering or the vanilla gets lost in the rest of the bold flavors.  The great brewers at Dieu du Ciel pulled this one off and I loved it!

Listed at Capones in Norristown PA as "APHRODITE", I consumed this brew on 4/18/10.

From notes...

Appearance: Dark as night - lifeless - like dolls eyes, minimal khaki crown, minimal retention, and minimal lace.

Smell: Loads of dark cocoa powder with a slight vanilla note.

Taste: Same as nose but not as pungent.

Mouthfeel: Creamy but a touch thin.

Drinkability: Smooth and easy going down.

Serving type: nitro-tap

Reviewed on: 05-10-2010

Aphrodite bottle. Pours black with a small tan head. Nose is vanilla bean, dark chocolate and coffee. Taste is vanilla bean, bakers chocolate and cocoa powder. Some dry malt on the finish. Lots of powder. Tasty overall stout.

Bottle. Nearly black. Lacking any real head. Aromas are as follows. Vanilla, chocolate, rockets candy,espresso and maple. Lots of flavor. Oatmeal, coffee, roasted malts, lots of chocolate, cocoa, and a nice burnt sweetness. Very long and bitter finish. I take points away based on the mouth feel being a bit too thin. Overall, this is fantastic.

Bottle. Full marks, its like an imperial. Aromas of chocolate, vanilla, and liquorice. Taste is sweet with bitter notes, long lasting. Palate is silky, and full bodied. Black, with a frothy off-white head.
Black in color with a decent tan head. Aroma is of chocolate, cocoa, coffee, hot chocolate and vanilla. Taste is of cocoa, vanilla, chocolate and coffee.

Draft at Gingerman NYC. And a pleasant surprise this one was. Pours deep black with tan head. Nose is full of cocoa, fresh vanilla and a touch of coffee. Very aromatic nose that keeps making you smile. On taste, very creamy, like chocolate milk. The chocolate and vanilla really feed into it. Not terribly complex but amazingly fun to drink. Excellent.

12 0z. bottle into a standard pint glass
An aggressive pour yielded an opaque black with a huge mocha-colored head which never completely dissapated.  Lacing is lasting as well.  Nose is not overwhelming - chocolate and vanilla prevail with some traces of roasted malt.  Taste is chocolate, vanilla a bready malt flavor and a nice semi-bitter finish with a little alcohol warming.  Very creamy and not overly thick mouthfeel.  Good carbonation.  This is a very tasty sipper and, except for the price, one I will want again.

Quite striking, the sweet mix of cocoa and vanilla dance across the nose, and down the back of the throat, on the back on a medium bodied, extremely smooth offering. About as good as good as a stout with all the added bells and whistles will get.
Had with the boys. The pour is dark thick body. Aroma is cocoa vanilla and a bit smoked. Amazing flavor of instant chocolate and lasting vanilla. So sweet.

Bottle. Pours black with a dark brown head. Aroma is nice with a strong vanilla note and underlying sweet chocolate and dark fruits. Flavor is much more bitter with roasted malts and bitter chocolate and just a bit of underlying vanilla. The vanilla is a bit stronger in the aftertaste.

Another Dieu du Ciel in a bottle (please... keep em coming). A nice stout with cocoa and vanilla beans. Pours a real dark brown that does not show any highlights through it. Good creamy and bubbly mocha-coloured head that is long lasting and creates thick wavy lacing. Roasted malt scent with notes of oats, molasses, dark fruits and cocoa. Smooth and silky mouthfeel. Great taste of roasted malt with the coffee really present in the finish. The vanilla comes out in the aftertaste as the bitter coffee continues on. I must say, the vanilla really blends well with the bitterness to make this brew very well-balanced. Another real treat from Dieu du Ciel.

On tap @ Spuyten Duyvil, NYC.  The aroma is chocolate, vanilla, roasty, and a slightly wierd lactic aroma.   The flavor is almost the same, sweet, chocolate, vanilla, sour milk.  The finish is roasty, vanilla flavors.  The beer is medium to medium thick in body.  Decent stout, not as good as expected.

Seems a thick type of stout all the better tan head dark coloured stout retention a plus aroma chocolate the cocoa so pronounced and good vanilla chocolate heaven flavour thick oily like it poured vanilla and cocoa taste malted chocolate light bitter flavour smooth sweet malt alround this stout is smooth aftertaste vanilla chocolate mild bitter very good indeed

Pours pitch black with a large, persistent, dark tan head.
Nose is not as complex as I expected, showing mostly charred wood (almost oaky) first up. Later on notes of milk chocolate and very subtle hints of vanilla are noticeable.
Chocolate is much more noticeable as a flavour, very creamy. Charred oak still present along with the subtle vanilla.
Good rich body, quite creamy. Carbonation is too high.

UPDATED: APR 14, 2011 Le liquide est profondément noir.  La tête mousse est foncée et résistante.  Une dentelle se dessine au contour du verre.  Le nez est très doux, délicieusement invitant: de la vanille et de la crème brulée saffirment à travers un malt chocolaté touché par les parfums succulents dun café glacé vietnamien.  Au goût, lattaque est directe de grains torréfiés amers qui se laissent subtilement enrober par des gousses de vanille et par un cacao pur.  En bouche, le liquide est étonnamment fort pour un stout.  Leffervescence, qui pique la langue, permet une parfaite diffusion des saveurs.  La finale est marquée par la torréfaction, par des saveurs asséchantes de café et de chocolat fin.  Est-ce déjà un classique?  (Revisité le 14 avril 2011)

11.5 oz. bottle from Wine and Cheese Place.  Pours a dark opauque brown with a tiny tan head that doesnt leave much of a trace.  Aroma of vanilla, bourbon, molasses, cocoa beans, toasted brown sugar, coffee, and maple syrup.  Flavor of roasted malts, coffee, cocoa beans, dirt, burnt toast, and metallic and mineral notes.  Medium-bodied, with low carbonation and a mineral mouthfeel.  Somewhat watered down feeling on the palate.  Bitter.  This starts off promising enough but falls kind of flat; disappointing.  Still a great aroma and not bad overall, but this has a really unusual mouthfeel that disguises the notes and is too thin.

SO YUMMY, SO VERY YUMMY!!!!!!! Dark brown almost no cap really just a thick bubble skim floating on top. Mmmmmmm.the aroma is a bakery combined with a coffee shop. Sweet vanilla, dark chocolate and rich coffee fill the nose. Oh man my drool glands are working aver time on this, I cant stop smelling it, I could just sit and smell this all day long and be happy. Taste is much of the same, smooth and sweet. A noticeable sweet alcohol that has a rum butter like taste turns bitter and ash like in the back of the throat. The vanilla is awesome in this brew its so sweet and creamy with a perfect bitterness. The malts are awesome just the right amount of burnt flavor to them. More spices are showing up now with raisins. The long lasting after taste is very coffee like but not a coffee bomb like some beers. I want to stock this as my every day stout but its too pricy but so dam good.

On tap.  Poured basically black with a thin layer of brown bubbles.  The aroma was tons of chocolate and vanilla with coffee coming out as well.  The flavor was mostly chocolate and vanilla and sugar.  Very little bitterness from hops or coffee.  Lacked balance.  The mouthfeel was full and silky.  Pretty good.

Bottle, 12C. Aroma is dominated by vanilla and its wild overtones. Theres dark chocolate and a bit of roast too. Very smooth texture with a bit of lightness added by remaining carbonation. No particular sweetness, but layers of coffee/ cocoa/ singed malt fattened up by vanilla. Finishes with refined roasty bitterness. I was half expecting to have to pick the vanilla seeds out of my teeth with this - its just a little over the top. Really good.

Pours jet black with decent tan head.  Appears rather oily along the sides of the glass.  Aroma initially dominated by sweet vanilla with more subtle hints of cocoa and toffee as it warms.  Palate is nice and full bodied and not oily like the appearance suggested.  Flavors of roasted malt, burnt wood, and bitter chocolate.  Finish is rather astringent with long lasting bitter cocoa flavors.  Pretty good beer but kinda disappointed that the vanilla beans add little except some aroma.

Very dark brown body with short lasting but good looking tan head. The aroma is lovely, chocolate, cocoa and hints of coffee. Taste follows the aroma pretty well, some burnt notes help it along, roasted bitterness.  Something I could drink plenty of.
From a Bottle. This is a phenomenal stout. Dark pour, with a beautiful mix of mild hop bitterness and sweet vanilla and chocolate.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2010 341mL bottle.  Pours opaque black with a chunky brown head that settles down somewhat.  Aroma of roast, chocolate and vanilla, just like it says on the box.  The flavour is dominated by the roast but otherwise balanced nicely.  Medium bodied, soft carbonation, silky smooth with a burnt bitter and slightly astringent finish.

Pours solid black, foamy reddish brown head. Aroma of milk chocolate, roast malt, fruit, mild hop, burnt. Taste is sweet with a slightly burnt flavor, lots of dark malts and some hops. Great balance and texture.

Poured a very dark brown-black and totally opaque. Decent i finger head faded into a nice ring. Smells of frsh vanilla been chocolates and some sweet caramel malt. Taste is big of vanilla and milk chocolate with a nice bitter accent in the finish. Body was a little soft however, Reminded me of a vanilla-d variety of Youngs dounble choclate stout, especially in the body. Big flavor lighter body.

Bottle. Dark brown body, thin buff head. Roasty nose with chocolate, somewhat acidic and woody. Crackery, toasty body, with chocolate, burnt brown sugars, and a bitter woody finish. Silky body with moderate heft. Fair complexity, but uninspiring.

Bottle purchased at Rozis.  Aroma is a wonderful marshmallowy sweet chocolate and roasted chestnuts.  Flavor is rich and roasted, lots of deep flavor with a little bit of chalky burnt texture.  Bitterness is simple and so mild, such a drinkable beer.

Poors oily black with a nice dense brown head. Aroma wasnt too powerfull at first, but as it heated, lots of sweet milky chocolate and cocoa came forth. The flavor was dominated by the coca, giving it a sweet desert like taste, afterwards the roasted malt have bitterness as balance. All in all a nice and highly drinkable stout.

Huge creamy dark lasting head with good lacing. Aroma of chocolate, coffee, vanilla, roasted and burnt malt. Full body creamy, thick and a bit sticky. Light bitter finish. The flavor is moderate sweet and light bitter - I guess from the roasted malt. A lovely beer with lot of taste and aromas. It reminds me of  Youngs Double Chocolate Stout, just better and more well balanced.

Bottle. Pours almost jet black with brownish ruby highlights and a foamy tan head that lasts a while. Aroma is quite roasty and has notes of vanilla, coffee, dark chocolate, malt and a hint of smoke. Flavour is also fairly roasty and has plenty of of vanilla and coffee, as well as some cocoa, but isnt particularly sweet. Light, creamy mouthfeel with low carbonation and a long, dry, bitter, roasty finish. A really good stout overall, not exactly a dessert beer, as I was kind of expecting, but just a well balanced, smooth, rich and compelling brew. Great stuff.

11.5 oz bottle as Aphrodite for #300. Black with a small tan head. Strong vanilla bean aroma backed by cocoa and cream. Flavor is once again heavy on the vanilla, which is almost matched by the dark chocolate flavors. Some coffee figures in there as well. Very nice, unique flavor.

The aroma of sweet creamy cocoa is so smooth in the nose, especially on nitrogen at Capones. The aroma might be better than a chocolate milkshake. The perfect appearance of a rich, chocolatey stout with a silky, creamy, cocoa head. The stout falls like velvet on the tongue, which I havent wrote on a rating in at least a year. The cocoa and vanilla blends perfectly on the palate as well with a creamy finish.

Quite enjoyable overall, but it did seem to be lacking something somewhere.  The vanilla and chocolatey notes were pretty spot on with a nice malty backbone holding everything together.  And is was velvety smooth, but something kept this beer from being exceptional.   Had my last bottle with a piece of Portillos chocolate cake.  That cannot be healthy, but sure was tasty.

Black pour with a reddish hue aroma of cocoa and vanilla with a tan head .... taste of bitter dark chocolate and vanilla, light roasted malts .... very smooth and rich light bitter hop finish ..... the aroma is amazing like opening a container of hersheys cocoa .... an amazing brew

After setting up a bunch of people on trades for this and never having it myself I finally caved.  Damn I should have had this a long time ago.  Pours a black viscous liquid with a brown head.  Aroma is intense cocoa and vanilla.  Taste is splendid.   Dark chocolates, vanilla, malt, milk chocolate.  Each flavour takes its turn to play on your tongue.  Im going to have this at much more frequency.
341ml bottle at Chancey Smiths, London.  Black pour with no head.  Nice aroma of vanilla.  Flavour was fruity, roasty, with a surprisingly bitter finish.  Very nice beer indeed.

12oz bottle purchased at BOTW. Pours a glossy black with a thin head of dark tan cream. The aroma is really impressive, with both the chocolate and vanilla well blended and strong. Sweet actually.  The flavor is very mild and easy to drink. The vanilla is very well done, if a touch too sweet. The chocolate is perfect and accents the character of the beer without defining it. A very nicely done creation.

Bottle labeled as Aphrodite. Pours a near pitch black color with a small tan colored head of foam that leaves small rings of lace around the glass. The aroma is very roasty with notes of bitter sweet chocolate, dark chocolate, hints of coffee, and earthy hops. The flavor is even better and more complex than the nose with loads of sweet milk chocolate and rich, dark chocolates up front followed by some cinnamon spices and vanilla beans. There is a touch of earthy hops on the back end along with some roast, which provides good balance between the chocolate sweetness. The depth of the chocolate flavor is really nice. Full bodied, smooth, and creamy on the mouthfeel with moderate carbonation that leads to a roasty cocoa finish. This is a great beer with a huge depth of flavors.

YES. YES. YES. What a wonderfull beer, what an symphonious beer, what a beer. Clicking on the words to the right seems pointless because an image is worth a thousand words but this beer is worth a vow of muting. Nothing could be improved. I dont usually rate beers with impressive grades but this one is worth the perfect score I gave.

341ml bottle, batch #9, whatever that means.  Pours quite thick black with a large three-finger plus brown head, foamy and rocky, leaves a clumpy ring of lacing and retains a good cap.  Aroma is rich dark chocolate, cocoa, and coffee, roasted malts, some vanilla.  Powerful and wonderful smelling beer.  First sip is an OMG moment if you are a chocolate lover, wow.  Massive amounts of premium dark chocolate, cocoa, some coffee, and to a lesser degree vanilla and roasted malts.  Cocoa definitely overpowers the nose and flavor, but thats not a bad thing at all, not at all.  Delicious.  Mouthfeel is rich, smooth, velvety, low carbonation, just about perfect.  This drinks so incredibly smoothly, tastes and smells so incredibly good, I want it to last forever but its going down so veyr, very fast.  Its a damned shame its $5.50 a bottle as Id buy this by the six on a regular basis.  Perhaps the best non-Imperial Stout Ive ever had.  Another phenomenal, world-class beer from Dieu du Ciel.  Cheers.

Aphrodite pours black with tan head. Nice vanilla mocha coffee aromas. medium body with a supersmooth mouthfeel. Awesome rich dark chocolate lactose, vanilla flavors with a deep roasted malt bitterness to balance.
user_location: Same Trailer, Different Park, Louisiana, USA

text: Bottle. Beautiful black color. Small brown head. Chocolate, roasted nut aroma. Nice rich, stout flavor, bitter but pleasant.

11.5oz twist off cap.  A somewhat vigorous pour yields a decent size beige head with black body.  Big sweet dark cocoa, a touch of coffee, vanilla, licorice and a touch of hazelnut.  Body is somewhat light for style and the carbonation is prickly.  Ashy chocolate and coffee, a chalky burnt maltines and a little on the sweet side...but the carbonation is just killing it for me; rough.

Out of the bottle.  Dark beer with a quickly dissappating brown head that left just a mist on the beers surface.  The aroma is dominated by the smell of expensive, dark chocolate.  Flavors of vanilla, chocolate frosting and bitter coffee.  Very complex chocolate flavors that balance the bitter with the sweet.  Very nice dessert beer.

Traveled all the way to Orlando for this one, but man was it worth it. The aroma has chocolate,coffee, and vanilla notes to it. The balance is incredible, no one flavor overpowers the next. Sits very well on the tongue.

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2013 330mL bottle, pours black with a small tan head. Aroma brings out loads of vanilla upfront, followed by sweetened cocoa. Flavour is very much the same, with a wonderful balance between the vanilla and cocoa. Very soft and delicate on the palate - certainly not a robust stout, but more like soft, velvety one with more delicate flavours. Wonderfully crafted.

Thanks to Jester for this one.
Pours black with a tan thin head.
Aroma is strong chocolate and coffee. Roasted malt.
Flavor is strong roasted malt, to the point it state like smoked malt and bark.
a pretty good beer.

Pours brown/black with a thin brown/beige head. Aroma and taste: bitter dark chocolate, coca beans, roasted malts, mild sweetness, notes of vanilla. Medium body, decent depth. Aftertaste of roasted malts and coca beans... a fairly short finish. Overall a very good dessert brew.

bottle of aphrodite from city beer.  pours a thick brwon with medium brwon head. the aroma has tons of vanila and cocoa, almost ST levels on the nose. taste is too match, very well balanced, bitter and sweet, chocolate and vanilla, roast and spice, great! palate is great, super smooth, goes down fast, excellent finish and aftertaste. def a top notch stout. i will be getting more of this.

12oz Bottle, purchased at Zenos Pub - State College, PA. Served at nearing warm temperature. Aroma is more or less a classic roast profile with a little added complexity and depth in the spice, earth, and chocolate field. Pours a deep black, with a lot of frothy caramel-colored head. Flavor jumps with character from the get-go, with noticeable bourbon vanilla, cacao nibs, and salted toffee coming through. Dense and with clean brown sugars and a long lay of roast on the palate afterwards. This is a very nice stout, with added richness from the vanilla and cacao additions, but in the bottle, its not world-class. However, I have not doubt that on a blend of nitrogen and carbon dixoide at the brewpub, this blows minds.
11.5 fl. oz. Bottle. Great beer.  Very smooth.  A beautiful dark brown/black color.  Aroma of chocolate/vanilla and some coffee.  Highly recommended.

Bottle.

Pours black with a beautiful medium light brown head. 

Inviting aroma of coffee, cocoa, vanilla, raisins and cookies. Taste of roasted sweet malt, coffee, vanilla, raisins and cookies. Very nice mouthfeel, smooth and milky. Soft carbonation, well-balanced and very drinkable. The finish was dry and rather bitter.

Bottle 11.5oz. - poured dark chocolate color with medium tam head.
Aroma - dark chocolate, coffee grounds and vanilla.
Flavor - vanilla, dark chocolate with bitter coco/coffee finish
Palate - heavy mouthfeel and thick texture. Finish is sewhat salty and bitter.
Overall - Excellent Stout, vanilla flavor works well with bitter dark chocolate taste! Little pricey but worth the try!

Good lacing.  Chocolate, vanilla, roasted malts.  Notes of bourbon, sweet malts and darkfruit.  The palate on this beer is unbelivable, smooth/milky/creamy.  Flavor has almost a chocolate milk reminder to it.
Pours black with a light brown head. Aroma is roasted malt, chocolate, vanilla and coffee. Flavour is roasted malt, chocolate, cocoa and light coffee. Nice.

11.5 oz bottle at Beer Bistro in Toronto, served in a half pint. Pours red-black with a rocky tan head. Poor head retention and poor lace. Aroma is impressive! lots of vanilla and dark chocolate along with molasses and roasted malts. A hint of floral hops rounds out the nose. Flavour is chocolate on a background of dry malts with a hint of vanilla. Finish is dry and hoppy. Full body with a smooth, creamy texture and soft carbonation. Overall, one of the best stouts out there. Aroma and flavour are unmatched. Appearance of the bottled version is not as great as the tap version at the brewpub, but flavours are intact. 2010-03-13

UPDATED: MAR 13, 2010 Pours black with a small tan head. Strong aroma of dark chocolate, coca, roasted malt., and a slight hint of vanilla. The flavor is similar. Medium to full bodied with little carbonation. Good stuff.

Pours pitch black with a thick tan head. Powerful aroma of chocolate, coffee, and vanilla. Flavor has a ton of bittersweet chocolate, roasted coffee and malt. No alcohol. A bit light on the body. I may be drinking this a bit too warm (60ish F), but its still good.

pours very deep brown...not quite black...oily looking with very subtle ruby hues.  medium sized deep mocha colored head.  aroma has cocoa, milkiness, a hint of fig, and roasty malts...also faint hop and metallic aromas.  flavor is very roasty, almost burnt at first but changes to cocoa and bitter espresso.  subtle metallic flavor too and a hint of dark fruit or fig.  not getting vanilla.  mouthfeel is creamy and thick with a very dry, lingering roasty burnt finish.

Pours dark brown and inky, nearly black in the glass, with a medium sized tan head, very fine lasting lacing.  Aromas of vanilla, chocolate, coffee, and molasses and leaves.  Medium-light body, velvety crisp and lively.  Initial sweetness, chocolate and vanilla, then some light bitterness, coffee, grass, and a tang of citrus.  Well balanced and highly quaffable.

From Knightly.  Black, dark brown edges, creamy tan head.  Aroma shows ash, chocolate, light coffee along with some vanilla.  Flavor is pretty much the same; a lot of dark chocolate along with espresso and vanilla.  Creamy palate with light bitter hops and roasty notes in the finish.  Well-balanced indeed.  I can see how this would be a terrific dessert beer.

UPDATED: FEB 7, 2011 [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, Feb 2011, 3.7: Strong sweet cocoa aroma. Opaque, brown head, good lace. Sweet, light bitter to bitter in the finish, loads of cocao with milk chocolate and a hint of coffee. [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */, Mar 2010, 2.7: Whats the fuzz about this beer? Except for the cocao its not that special. And the roasted malts taste like ashes next to the cocao. Could use some body too.

Gonna say it now: a little overrated.  But damn good. Black pour with fair layer of tan head. Nose of smoke, big roast, chocolate, which comes out more in the flavor.  Big hop bitterness on the tail.  Dont really pick up the vanilla so much, but still, tasty beer.

12oz bottle.  Pours a dark black with a thin tan head.  Smells great, like chocolate with a bit of roast.  Taste is a great balance of roasty chocolate, vanilla, and a touch of bitterness in the finish.
Bottle.  Black with a laced brown head.  A strong vanilla and chocolate aroma.  A smooth vanilla chocolate roasted malt flavors and a delightful finish.

Pours a one finger light tan head that fades quickly to a thin ring, leaving no lace. Black color, no highlights. Vanilla and cocoa nose. Light carbonation and heavy bodied. Flavor is almost burnt coffee balanced by a smooth, sweet vanilla. Expensive at $7.00 for a 11.5oz bottle from Tullys Beer & Wine Wells, Me.

Bottle to pint glass.  Black pour with a two inch tan head. Aroma of cocoa, vanilla, and maybe smoke. Flavors of dark chocolate, vanilla, roasted malt, a touch of hops. Really like the eveness between vanilla and cocoa in this.  Lives up to the rating, re-buy for sure.

Black thin tan head. Aroma-roasted malts, chocolate, vanilla. Taste-chocolate, vanilla, roasted malt. Tons of flavor. Authentic cocoa and vanilla flavors. Perfect sweetness. A bit thin bodied is the only drawback.

Dark and reddish, with a tan head and traces of it stay around.  Very heavy cocoa nose, also some roasted malt.  Palate is great at 1st sip, gritty, chocolaty, malty, hoppy, well-balanced.   I dont get a lot in the complexity department though, keeping this from the upper echelon, but heck this is a nice beer.

Pours black with a small brown head. Aroma of deep cocoa. Flavor is roasted malts, some chocolate, a little vanilla on the tail end. The beer is pretty complex despite its unexpected lighter flavor. Starts sweet and then has a little bit of a bitter finish. Very smooth and clean on the palate. This is good but I was expecting stronger flavors.

Bottle. black pour with a cocoa head. Aroma of light boozey fruits, dark chocolate, a bit of smoke and roast with some vanilla as well. Flavors of milk chocolate, vanilla, light roasted malt, a bit of ash. Medium-ish body, roasty, bitter/sour, pleasantly sweet, ashy,...lingering finish. Not bad, but not worth all the hype its gotten, nor its price tag. Peche is far and away the superior stout they brew.

Bottle from Bruisin. Pours a rich dark near-black with ruby tints and a ring of a tan head. The aroma has lots of vanilla and chocolate, it seems a little sharp. The palate is fairly creamy but has some tickling carbonation. Lots of vanilla bean and chocolate flavor are very apparent. I never really got into the use of vanilla in beers. This is fair but it doesnt exactly float my boat. Its too much like a vanilla dessert for me. That being said, it isnt bad. Ive got no problem drinking a bottle every now and then. Pretty good stout, but nowhere near the awesomeness of their Peche Mortel.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a clear dark brown body with a small fizzy brown head that faded to a wispy film and a thick ring.  Great deep nose full of roast, milk chocolate, vanilla beans, some earthy yeast.  Amazingly rich cocoa notes.  The flavor is not nearly as deep and rich as the aroma would lead on.  The vanilla and cocoa are still pretty nice, but the malt depth just isnt doing everything that it should be doing for me.  I think that it just doesnt all meld well.  The lingering vanilla note comes across a bit extract like on the finish. I like the sweet and bitter balance thats going on here though.   Medium bodied with a fairly nice slightly chewy texture and soft carbonation.  Its probably a shame that this beer is lumped in with the original version cause it seems a long way away from a "Top 50" caliber beer.

There are far too few outstanding single stouts out there, a gap which this bottle fills ably.  Overpowering dark chocolate and vanilla with a backing of roastiness in a package that drinks extremely smoothly.  If I could get this regularly and cheap Id drink it by the case.

355ml bottle (Pikkulintu, Helsinki)
Aroma or vanilla and chocolate. Whisky or bourbon taste, and cocoa. Roast and bitter aftertaste which might give some hint of beer. Doesnt have enough beer in it to be a stout, this is instead more of a gimmick with all its annoyingly fashionable additives.

Finally getting around to rating this.  Thanks Chuck.  The beer pours to a pitch black body with a light khaki head.  The aroma is super sweet vanilla and sweet milk chocolate.  Light bourbon.  The aroma is very much an aphrodisiac.  Sex in a bottle.  The flavor is super sweet vanilla bean ice cream, dry cocoa powder, powdered malted barley, and a bit of charred wood on the finish.  The palate actually works and is clean and non-sticky.  Seemingly it adds to the overall experience rather than being a big imperial stout.

Nearly jet black pour w/ a big light brown head and decent lacing, but the head does fade fairly quickly.  Aroma is SIMPLY MOUTHWATERING.  My buddy said sex in a bottle, and I didnt even make fun of him!  Great sweet vanillas a touch of butter nice roasty lightly bitter chocolate a hint of bitterness reminds me of sweet vanilla coffee w/ some chocolate.  MMMM! Palate is nice, but not thick or creamy enough.  Flavor has quite a bit of cocoa bitterness on the front the vanilla is the secondary flavor coming through after the bitter cocoa fades a dry & sweet stout some good roasty toasty malts hints of lactose before they are buried by the bigger flavors.  I might just say the best non imperial stout Ive ever sampled.

Dieu Du Ciel
Aphrodite
Pours very dark with almost no head. Oily with some lacing on the glass. Slight bubbles are always present on the surface. Aroma coffee, cocoa, soy sauce and molasses sweetness. Slight alcohol on the aroma. Taste is very smooth with a woody presence. Hints of vanilla and coffee. Nothing stands out, and that is why I am not enamored. It is really good, but it left me wanting more.

Bottled at Tipu. Black, firm cappucino head. Nose is very mellow, soft vanilla, some honey, dry roasted malt, hints of lactose. Flavor has honeyish bourbon vanilla, whipped cream, little sugariness, dryish burned malt, hints of yeastiness, a bit hollow coffeeish finish, little hard water. Medium bodied, could still use a tad smoother carbonation, reasonably. A good, harmonious stout, Id love this see this on tap.

From a 12 oz. bottle with Aphrodite on the label courtesy of Strykzone.  This poured a dense black with a large fluffy dark tan head with light lacing and not much retention. The nose is dominated by the vanilla with some chocolate.   Medium body and rich mouthfeel. The flavor is also strongly of the vanilla with toasted malts and  chocolate.  The finish is long and bitter. This would be a really outstanding beer if is was better balanced, but there was just a little too much vanilla and it threw off the balance some.

Bottle; courtesy of my sister for Xmas.  Poured a dark brown color with an almost creamy looking brown head.  Aroma of roasted malt, vanilla, cocoa, with light coffee, smoky and earthy notes.  Vanilla added a nice balance.  Flavor was as equally delicately balanced.  Vanilla and roasted/coffee/smoky notes.  A little bit of earthy hops in the finish.  Would have liked a longer finish, or at least a more pronounced one. Worth the praise it receives.

Bottle/12 - Poured a very dark black/brown in color with a small thick-bodied tan head that settled to a thin covering over the beer.  Really nice lacing.  Aroma is of dark chocolate, vanilla and cocoa powder.  Flavor is very chocolate with a nice amount of vanilla.  Some hop bitterness, but not much of their flavor.  Finish is lingering, chocolaty and slightly bitter with a bit of astringency.  Really nice... dont drink this one too cold as youll miss much of the flavor!!

Bottle on Valentines Day, shared with my wife. Pours deep, dark brown with a ring of tan foam.  Aroma is a gorgeous blend of vanilla and chocolate brownies. Taste is rich chocolate, coffee and vanilla.  Lingering bitter chocolate finish. Mouthfeel is rich, but a wee too carbonated.  Would love to try this sexy beast on nitro someday.

Pours dark brown / black with a thin tan head.  The nose is faint roasted malt  and cocoa.  The flavors are heavy vanilla and cocoa with some dark fruit.  The bitterness is just about right.  The carbonation is a bit too much, though overall the beer has a nice creamy mouth feel.  A nice stout.
black pour with a big chocolate cocoa aroma.  The flavor has some dark chocolate and vanilla that balances it out nicely.

THOUGHTS: Wonderful stout. A little heavy on the vanilla, but thats what makes it unique. It also works well with the other flavors here. The cocoa is there, but the vanilla is the true star here.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a dark brown that was an opaque black in the glass with red highlights at the very edge and an average tan to light brown head that kept a thin sheet and left fair lacing. The aroma was moderate to heavy roasted, milk chocolate and cocoa malts; and vanilla. The initial flavor was sweet, lightly bitter and acidic; while the finish was bitter, rather acidic and sweet with a long duration. There was vanilla, cocoa, coffee, bitter chocolate and roasted malt. The medium to full body was silky with carbonation that was a bit soft with a chalky and slightly metallic finish.

Bottle.  Pours a luxurious black with a rich tan head that laces nicely down the glass.  Aroma is chocolate and roasted malt, no vanilla.  Taste is bitter chocolate with a finish of cream soda.  Very nice.  Sweet but not cloying  On tap this is a 5/5 beer
Bottle: pours dark black with a thin tan head, aroma of chocolate, vanilla, taste of roasted malts, chocolate, coffee, some vanilla, mildly bitter, medium bodied

Pours very dark brown with a large dense dark tan head.  The aroma has very roasted malt, lots of smooth chocolate, slight vanilla notes and dark caramel.  This is very lush, smooth and rich without being too sweet.  Medium body thats thinner than expected.  Its smooth with a little bit of graininess and has some fairly soft carbonation.  The flavor starts with roasted malt along with earthy and spicy hops along with some cocoa, a bit of spritziness and light coffee notes.  The finish gets a bit creamier and displays dark chocolate and a lightly burnt malt taste.  It would be nice if the vanilla stood out a bit more, but this is still an absolutely fantastic stout.

Bottle from my main man StFun  thanks Josh!  Pours crude oil black with a 2 finger dense brown head.  The nose is roast, vanilla, cocoa, coffee and chocolate.  The taste is burnt malt, dark roast coffee, ash, vanilla and dark fruits with a slight bitter finish.  Medium creamy mouthfeel.  Damn good Stout.  Thanks again J for sending this my way!

12oz bottle sampled at Sexual Chocolate Day 2010.  Watery, opaque black with light, cloudy tan head.  Nose is SUPER chocolatey, almost like a liquid candy bar, nuts, light coffee with cream.  Flavor is very sweet but not disgustingly sweet, brown sugar, nice cake icing, light toast, light coffee with cream.  Finish is super smooth, very drinkable.
Dark brown with a medium deep beige head. Sweet aroma with hard roasted malt, chocolate and coffee notes. Flavour was sweet with hard roasted malt, dark chocolate, coffee and vanilla. Finished dry.

34.1 cL bottle. Pours pitch black with a small creamy and chocolate brown head. Aroma is dark chocolate and coffee, roasted malt and light herbal touch. Light vanilla note. Smooth and chocolate flavoured with a smooth vanilla note. Lingering dark chocolate and vanilla finish.

Bottle 34,1 cl. Courtesy of yespr. Pours an opaque deep dark  brown with a vague tint of red and a creamy light brown head. Aroma is sweet milk chocolate. Medium body, dry burned malts and loads of cocoa powder and sweet milk chocolate. Some malt bitterness in the finish. 080210

If this was affordable, itd be a staple for me.  Its about as close too the edge of beer as you can get without  forgetting your drinking a beer.  The aroma is full of caramel, chocolate, coffee, espresso, and roasted malts.  The hobs are muted.  The adjuncts give everything from alcohol to banana, licorice, vanilla, and smoke.  The appearance is the only issue of concern here it is dark opaque black body with mininimal brass colored thin collar  The beer looks exactly like an espresso.
